bioghist.p: Richard Robert Wright, Jr. (1878-1967) was a bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal (A.M.E.) Church. He served as editor of the Christian Recorder, business manager of the A.M.E. Book Concern, and president of Wilberforce University. He was well known for his literary works in A.M.E. Church history and American sociology. Ruth Wright-Hayre (1910-1998), the daughter of R.R. Wright, Jr., was the first full-time African American teacher in the Philadelphia public school system, the first African American senior high school principal, as well as the first female president of the Philadelphia Board of Education. For her advocacy programs in support of urban teenagers in Philadelphia, Ms. Hayre received honors and awards from dozens of local and national organizations, including the University of Pennsylvania and the NAACP. Her memoir, written with Alexis Moore and Ed Bradley, is entitled Tell Them We Are Rising: A Memoir of Faith in Education.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection documenting the career of R.R. Wright, Jr. as a bishop of the A.M.E. Church and as a professor and president of Wilberforce University and to his involvement in politics. Materials in the collection include: newspaper articles by and about Wright (1936-1966), scrapbooks of news clippings, and printed material related to church activities and to the presidential campaigns of 1936 and 1940; a photo album from Wilberforce University and miscellaneous photographs; printed programs, reports, brochures, newsletters and magazines; bound copies of the Christian Recorder (1943-1947); announcements for church, cultural, and political programs and events; correspondence related to and from R.R. Wright and the General Board of the church, related to church activities and finances; a small number of financial records, including receipts, check stubs, and a ledger; The collection also includes movies from South Africa, Haiti, Cuba, St. Croix, and Santo Domingo.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
